Chapter 3 Data transformation From the official website, we get separate csv files for different variables, including total number of incidents, in years from 2014 to 2018. First of all, we transform those csv files into dataframes in R. # Read the incident files into dataframes incident_2014 <- read.csv("./data/incident_2014.csv") incident_2015 <- read.csv("./data/incident_2015.csv") incident_2016 <- read.csv("./data/incident_2016.csv") incident_2017 <- read.csv("./data/incident_2017.csv") incident_2018 <- read.csv("./data/incident_2018.csv") death_2014 <- read.csv("./data/death_2014.csv") death_2015 <- read.csv("./data/death_2015.csv") death_2016 <- read.csv("./data/death_2016.csv") death_2017 <- read.csv("./data/death_2017.csv") death_2018 <- read.csv("./data/death_2018.csv") The codes written above are for examples of our way of transforming from csv files into dataframes in R.
